```for (nproc, color) in zip(unique(dtable.procs), colors)

end```

text: Yes we don't have any color cycling yet, so you're not missing something obvious. My problem so far is that I don't know how to correctly handle all the different possible plot types correctly. They could have unusually named attributes, not just `color`. Should lines and linesegments etc run on the same cycler because they're lines? How about poly, barplot, etc. I do want to make this simpler with Axis but I'm not sure yet what's the easiest, most robust implementation

text:
`data(dtable) * style(:scale, :time, color = :nproc => categorical) * visual(Lines)` should describe the plot you need in AlgebraOfGraphics, then you can just call `draw` on the result to visualize it.

There was a PR to allow for this to be possible without changing syntax, but it may take a while to happen: <https://github.com/JuliaPlots/AlgebraOfGraphics.jl/issues/136|https://github.com/JuliaPlots/AlgebraOfGraphics.jl/issues/136>

elements.text: data(dtable) * style(:scale, :time, color = :nproc => categorical) * visual(Lines)
should describe the plot you need in AlgebraOfGraphics, then you can just call
draw

on the result to visualize it.

https://github.com/JuliaPlots/AlgebraOfGraphics.jl/issues/136

plt2 = scatter!(ax, args...) # for the remaining traces```

text:
or one explicit axis and then only mutation
```f[i, j] = Axis(f)
scatter!(args...) # should not need ax as current_axis() is called```

text:
each layoutable is made by `Layoutable(figure)` but then you do `fig[i, j] = ...` to actually place them in a meaningful layout position. It would be nice if we could do
```f[1, 2] = Axis()```
but then the axis would have to be able to exist without a figure and we don't have the infrastructure for such standalone objects
